Animating grid-template-rows from 0fr to 1fr allows you to transition an element from zero to its natural content height â€” without JavaScript measurements or the max-height hack. The inner element uses overflow: hidden to clip during the transition.

The max-height approach requires setting an arbitrary large value (e.g., 1000px), which causes the easing curve to feel wrong â€” the animation "hangs" at the end because it's still transitioning through invisible space. The grid trick avoids this entirely.

The curve cubic-bezier(0.34, 1.56, 0.64, 1) goes slightly past 1.0 in its Y range, creating a real overshoot effect. This is the closest you can get to a true spring with CSS without JavaScript. Combine it with a 400ms duration for a natural feel.

Demo 37

Gradient Text Hue Shift

Text with animated gradient background that shifts hue and saturation as you scroll down the page. Pure CSS + GSAP ScrollTrigger.

How It Works

This effect uses CSS Custom Properties (CSS variables) to dynamically control the hue, saturation, and lightness of a gradient background applied to text.

As the user scrolls, GSAP ScrollTrigger updates the CSS variables in real-time, creating a smooth color shift that feels organic and modern.

The Technique

A heading element uses background: linear-gradient(...) with CSS variables for hue rotation. Each section has its own hue range.

The effect is simple but impactful: as you scroll past, the text color smoothly transitions through the color spectrum.

Perfect For

  • Hero sections: Draw attention with color-shifting headlines
  • Section headers: Visual rhythm and engagement
  • Feature callouts: Highlight key messages
  • Portfolio pages: Modern, eye-catching typography
  • Marketing sites: Brand color integration and movement

Advanced Variations

You can layer multiple hue shifts, adjust saturation for desaturation on scroll, or synchronize the shift with other animations on the page.

The gradient direction can also be linked to scroll velocity for even more dynamism.

Implementation

  1. Define CSS variables for hue: --hue: 0deg
  2. Apply gradient to text: background: linear-gradient(to right, hsl(var(--hue), 100%, 50%), ...)
  3. Use background-clip: text to show only the gradient on text
  4. Update --hue with ScrollTrigger's onUpdate callback
  5. Wrap in prefers-reduced-motion check for accessibility

Responsive & Accessible

The effect gracefully degrades on browsers without gradient text support. When prefers-reduced-motion is enabled, the gradient is static or removed entirely.

A Visual Journey

The Amalfi Coast

Where Sea Meets Sky

Along the southern edge of Italy's Sorrentine Peninsula, the Amalfi Coast unfolds like a watercolor painting left out in the Mediterranean sun. Pastel villages cling to limestone cliffs that plunge dramatically into turquoise waters, while terraced lemon groves perfume the salt-tinged air with citrus sweetness.

This stretch of coastline has inspired artists, poets, and wanderers for centuries. Every turn in the winding road reveals another vista that seems too beautiful to be real â€” a composition of color and light that no camera can fully capture.

"The coast is a place where time moves differently â€” not faster or slower, but in waves."

The ancient towns of Positano, Amalfi, and Ravello each possess their own character. Positano cascades down its cliff face in a tumble of pink, terracotta, and white. Amalfi's cathedral rises from its piazza like a jewel. Ravello floats above it all, its gardens offering views that stretch to the edge of the world.

01 The Cliffs of Positano
02 Mediterranean Waters
03 Golden Hour
04 The Village at Dusk

Stories from the Coast

The Coastal Path

The Sentiero degli Dei â€” the Path of the Gods â€” winds along the ridgeline high above the sea, offering views that ancient Greeks believed were worthy of Olympus itself.

Starting from the town of Agerola, the trail descends gradually through terraced hillsides thick with Mediterranean scrub. Wild rosemary and thyme release their fragrance underfoot. To one side, the cliff drops hundreds of meters to the sea below; to the other, the peaks of the Lattari Mountains rise into wisps of cloud.

It takes roughly four hours to complete the walk, ending with a steep descent into Nocelle and onward to Positano. But no one rushes this path. Every bend invites you to stop, to breathe, to absorb a panorama that shifts with the light.

Limoncello Sunset

The lemons of the Amalfi Coast are unlike any others in the world â€” enormous, fragrant, and sweet enough to eat raw, their thick rinds holding centuries of tradition.

In the terraced groves that climb the hillsides, the sfusato amalfitano lemons grow under canopies of chestnut poles and straw mats. These are not the small, tart lemons of commerce â€” they are giants, sometimes the size of a grapefruit, with rinds so aromatic they perfume entire valleys.

At sunset, when the golden light catches the fruit hanging heavy on the branches, you understand why limoncello became the coast's signature drink. The recipe is simple: lemon zest, sugar, water, alcohol. The magic is in the lemons themselves.

Fisherman's Dawn

Before the tourists wake, before the cafes open their shutters, the fishermen of Cetara have already been at sea for hours, continuing a tradition as old as the coast itself.

Cetara is the quietest of the Amalfi Coast towns, overlooked by most visitors in favor of its more photogenic neighbors. But it is here, in this small harbor village, that you find the coast's oldest and most authentic tradition: the colatura di alici, an anchovy sauce descended directly from the Roman garum.

The fishermen set out in darkness, navigating by the stars and the feel of the current. They return with the dawn, their small boats heavy with the silver catch that will be salted, pressed, and aged into liquid gold.

Every journey begins with a single step.

Words by Elena Voss — Summer 2025 — 8 min read

snippets.html:
Demo 39

Velocity-Aware Scroll

Scroll faster to see speed lines intensify. The canvas layer reacts to scroll velocity â€” the faster you scroll, the stronger the visual feedback.

Scroll Speed Detection

Lenis provides real-time velocity data through its scroll event. We map that velocity to visual intensity â€” opacity, line count, and blur all scale with how fast you scroll.

Slow scrolling produces minimal effect. Fast scrolling creates a dramatic speed-lines tunnel on the Canvas overlay.

Canvas Speed Lines

A Canvas 2D layer sits fixed behind the page. On each animation frame, lines radiate from the center at lengths proportional to the scroll velocity magnitude.

The visual effect is inspired by motion blur in photography and the speed lines used in action manga. Faster scroll = more lines, higher opacity, longer streaks.

Parallax Intensity

Parallax layers in the background also react to velocity. Faster scrolling temporarily increases the parallax offset multiplier, creating a sense of dimensional acceleration through space.

This effect is commonly used in gaming landing pages, sportswear brands, and esports tournament sites.

Performance

The effect is optimized for 60fps using:

  • Canvas clearRect + redraw on each rAF tick (no DOM mutations)
  • Velocity decay â€” speed lines fade naturally when scrolling slows
  • Line count cap to prevent overdraw on slow devices
  • Disabled entirely if prefers-reduced-motion is active

Implementation Details

Access Lenis velocity via lenis.on('scroll', ({ velocity }) => ...). The velocity value is a float between roughly -30 and +30 depending on scroll speed.

Map the absolute value to your visual parameters:

  • lineCount = Math.min(maxLines, Math.abs(velocity) * 5)
  • lineLength = Math.abs(velocity) * 20 pixels
  • opacity = Math.min(0.8, Math.abs(velocity) * 0.05)

SVG Workflow Animation

SVG paths draw themselves as you scroll, with nodes and labels appearing in sequence. A clean way to visualize processes, timelines, and workflows.

How It Works

The key CSS property is stroke-dasharray and stroke-dashoffset. By setting the dashoffset to the full path length and animating it to 0, the path appears to "draw itself."

GSAP ScrollTrigger measures the path length with path.getTotalLength() at initialization, then animates the offset during scroll using scrub: 1 for direct scroll-position linking.

Step-by-Step

  1. Get path length: const len = path.getTotalLength()
  2. Set initial state: path.style.strokeDasharray = len, path.style.strokeDashoffset = len
  3. Animate: gsap.to(path, { strokeDashoffset: 0, scrollTrigger: { scrub: 1 } })

The Digital Atelier

Thoughts on design, code, and craft

Design 5 min read

The Art of Digital Minimalism

In an era of information overload, the most powerful design choice is often what you leave out. Minimalism in digital design is not about austerity â€” it is about intentionality, clarity, and respect for the viewer's attention.

Read article
Code

Composability Over Complexity

The best codebases are not the ones with the cleverest abstractions. They are the ones where every piece does one thing well and combines naturally with the rest.

Maya Chen Feb 8, 2026

There is a moment in every growing codebase when complexity begins to feel inevitable. Features pile onto features, edge cases multiply, and the once-clean architecture starts to buckle under the weight of pragmatic decisions. This is the inflection point where most teams reach for heavyweight frameworks, elaborate design patterns, or multi-layered abstractions to restore order.

But there is another path. Composability â€” the practice of building software from small, self-contained units that combine predictably â€” offers a more sustainable answer. The Unix philosophy captured this decades ago: write programs that do one thing well and work together through simple interfaces. The same principle translates directly to modern frontend components, backend services, and even infrastructure.

Consider a function that formats a date, another that fetches user data, and a third that renders a profile card. Each is trivially testable in isolation. Composed together, they produce a complete feature. When requirements change â€” and they always do â€” you replace or modify a single piece without destabilizing the whole. This is not elegance for its own sake; it is a practical strategy for teams that need to move quickly without accumulating technical debt.

Craft

The Quiet Power of Typography

Typography is the invisible architecture of every interface. When it works, nobody notices. When it fails, everything feels wrong.

Liam Hartwell Jan 24, 2026

We spend our days immersed in type without thinking about it. The size of a heading, the spacing between lines, the weight of a label â€” these micro-decisions accumulate into something larger: the feeling of using a product. A cramped paragraph signals carelessness. Generous whitespace between sections creates breathing room that lets ideas land. The typeface you choose for body copy communicates more than the words themselves â€” it sets a tone before a single sentence is read.

The best typographic systems are invisible precisely because they have been obsessively considered. They establish hierarchy without shouting, guide the eye without arrows, and create rhythm without decoration. A well-set page is like a well-conducted orchestra: the individual instruments disappear into the coherence of the whole.

For digital products, this means treating typography as a first-class design decision rather than an afterthought. Define a type scale early. Set line heights that give text room to breathe â€” typically 1.5 to 1.7 for body text. Limit yourself to two typefaces at most. And test your typography at every viewport: what feels spacious on a desktop can become suffocating on a phone. The goal is not beauty for its own sake, but communication made effortless.

Design

Designing for Slow Attention

Not every interaction needs to be instant. Sometimes the most respectful design is one that gives people space to think before they act.

Sofia Reyes Jan 11, 2026

Speed has become the default metric of digital quality. Faster load times, quicker interactions, shorter paths to conversion â€” the industry optimizes relentlessly for velocity. But speed is not always a virtue. In contexts that involve reflection, commitment, or emotional weight, designing for speed can actually undermine the experience.

Consider the difference between deleting a file and deleting an account. Both are destructive actions, but one is trivially reversible and the other carries genuine consequence. A confirmation dialog that appears and vanishes in milliseconds does not give someone space to truly consider what they are about to do. A brief pause, a clear explanation of what will happen, a moment of intentional friction â€” these are not obstacles. They are acts of care.

Designing for slow attention means recognizing that some moments deserve more weight than others. It means using animation not to dazzle but to orient. It means writing interface copy that acknowledges the gravity of a decision rather than burying it in corporate euphemism. The goal is not to slow everything down, but to be thoughtful about where speed helps and where it harms. In a world that demands constant acceleration, deliberately slowing down at the right moments is a radical design choice.

snippets.html:
Technique Demo

GSAP Accordion

Height animation from 0 â†’ auto using GSAP's height tweening. Each panel collapses and expands with spring easing. Multiple variants: exclusive, multi-open, and nested.

Variant A

Exclusive â€” one open at a time

A GSAP accordion animates panel height from 0 to its natural content height using gsap.to(el, { height: 'auto' }). Unlike CSS transitions which can't animate from height: 0 to height: auto, GSAP handles this seamlessly by calculating the target height internally.

The key is pairing overflow: hidden on the container with a GSAP tween that toggles autoAlpha and height together for a smooth reveal.

GSAP's gsap.to(el, { height: 'auto', duration: 0.5 }) works by measuring the element's scrollHeight at tween start, then animating from current to that value. Combine with ease: 'expo.out' for a natural deceleration.

To collapse, use gsap.to(el, { height: 0 }) â€” GSAP handles the measurement automatically.

The CSS max-height trick requires setting a large arbitrary maximum (e.g., max-height: 1000px), which causes easing to feel wrong â€” the element accelerates until it hits the actual content height, then stops abruptly.

GSAP measures the real target height and creates a precise, spring-eased animation with no easing artifacts.

Always set aria-expanded on the trigger button and toggle it on state change. The panel body should have a matching aria-hidden attribute. Screen readers need these attributes to announce the expanded/collapsed state correctly.

For prefers-reduced-motion, skip the tween and immediately set the final state using gsap.set().

View Transitions API

The document.startViewTransition() method captures before/after snapshots and animates between them using CSS pseudo-elements.

Circular Wipe

A custom ::view-transition-new(root) animation uses clip-path: circle() expanding from the toggle button position.

CSS Custom Properties

Theme colors are defined as CSS variables on [data-theme]. The transition swaps theme by toggling this attribute.

The Art of Transitions

A well-crafted theme transition doesn't just swap colors â€” it tells a story. The circular wipe radiates from the point of interaction, creating a clear cause-and-effect relationship that feels natural and intentional.

How It Works

This technique uses GSAP's TextPlugin combined with ScrollTrigger to animate numeric values from 0 to a target number while the user scrolls. The counter respects scrub: true, meaning the animation is directly linked to scroll position â€” scroll faster, the numbers update faster.

Key Features

  • Scroll-synced: Counter animation is tied directly to scroll progress using scrub
  • Decimal support: Handles percentages, decimals, and large numbers with thousand separators
  • Staggered reveal: Each card animates in sequence as you scroll past
  • Reduced motion: Counters are skipped if user prefers no motion
  • Performance optimized: Uses integer rendering to avoid excessive DOM updates

Use Cases

Perfect for:

  • Portfolio showcase pages (project counts, years of experience)
  • SaaS landing pages (user counts, uptime metrics)
  • Case studies (improvement percentages, revenue impact)
  • Company stats pages (customers served, transactions processed)

Integration Tips

To use this in your own projects:

  1. Import GSAP and TextPlugin: import { TextPlugin } from 'gsap/TextPlugin'
  2. Register the plugin: gsap.registerPlugin(TextPlugin)
  3. Use scrub: true to link animation to scroll position
  4. Customize formatting with formatUnits callback for decimals/prefixes
  5. Wrap in ScrollTrigger to trigger when card enters viewport
